For example, in the context of Diffie-Hellman keys, two large Blum integers are chosen and made public. Later, both parties share a different integer 'a' which is raised to the power of those two Blum integers and sent back. The parties then compute a private key by taking the inverse modulo and can securely communicate based on those two keys. 

On the other hand, the Merkle-Hellman knapsack cipher uses a composite number for the Blum integer. In this case, two public keys P and Q are generated, the first Blum-integer P and the second corresponding to a non-coprime Blum-integer (thus P and Q being able to be factored to their respective primes) Q.
